nodes.bodyText: Can we push the sorting to the spark shuffle machinery? repartitionAndSortWithinPartitions(). It cheap and practically free

We already sort using RDD.sortBy()
(see WriteHandle.java)
taggedRecords.sortBy(r -> r.getRecordKey(), true, taggedRecords.getNumPartitions());
Merging has some additional complication:
During merging, we are reading existing records (which should be sorted in HFile) and updating a "few" of them. Then we are writing all of them back to a new HFile. So effectively, we have two sorted list of records:

The records being read from existing HFile (sorted in last write)
The records being updated (sorted in WriteHandle code)

We can do it in three steps but this will require a large amount of memory or an ExternalSpillableMap:

Read all records from existing HFile
Apply updates in-memory
Write to new HFile

The way I have implemented is like a merge-sort which does not require reading all the records from the HFile before applying updates.
Can we have HashBasedJoin and SortMergeJoin as first level abstractions which both taken in 2 streams of records to be merged ? We can then plugin the algorithm depending on storage preference.

If we push sorting to spark, then all the iterators fed to create/merge/append handle will sort records by records key.. for merge handle we can do a simple merge sort style sort merge (instead of hash merge). We just assert that both existing files and incoming records are sorted

The advantage is more modularity as well as low memory overhead to merge..
Note that we don’t do this for data today because we may not necessarily want the data Sorted by key

In my changes:

Spark based sorting is used (see WriteHandle.java)
Sorting is ONLY done if format requires it (so there is no change to Parquet format)
Merge style sort is implemented



The advantage is more modularity as well as low memory overhead to merge..
Yes, that was my vision too.
I did not review this block too closely. Let’s settle on the high level approach first
Sure. BTW this is the merge sort style merge you pointed in the previous comment.
HFilev itself contains bloom filters right.. why do we need them outside?

HFile allows adding BloomFilters using an interface. They are not always present (i.e. there is no AvroWriteSupport kind of implementation).
I think there are some benefits to using Hoodie's BloomFilter:

If we use HBase's implementation of BloomFilter, we will have to convert it to HoodieBloom filter as Hoodie code uses HoodieBloomFilter in functions
Advances in Hoodie's Bloom filter (compression, dynamic sizing) etc will not be available to HFile format
Common interface across all base file formats so easier to maintain in the long run and easier to update

okay. I was thinking about dynamic sizing as well . 2.
So IIUC, HFile does natively support serializing a bloom filter with the file? and thats why we take advantage of?

Nope. We are serializing the HoodieBloomFilter to bytes and saving this as a metadata block in HFile. HFile has support for adding custom named blocks of data which are loaded on demand (unlike Parquet Footer which is always read).
HFile has its own interface BloomFilters which can also be implemented by HoodieBloomFilter. But that sounds overkill to me.
As more base file formats are added, I think we should focus on common functionality so that we prevent code duplication.
I think the dynamic bloom is reason enough. So good here
StorageWriter is not a great name really.. let’s rename consistently to HoodieFileWriter/HoodieFileWriterFactory?

We have a family of things that needs to be constructed:

StorageWriter
StorageReader
MergeAlgorithm

In this case, AbstractFactoryPattern would be useful  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_factory_pattern#/media/File:Abstract_factory_UML.svg  pattern would be ideal for this case.
This is more or less similar to what has been done here. Currently, there is a separate Writer and Reader Factory. What do you think about creating an AbstractFactory and have one concrete implementation for Parquet and another for HFile  where all the above objects are constructed ?

I have created the new HoodieSortedMergeHandle which extends the HoodieMergeHandle. This way, the sort functionality is moved to the HoodieSortedMergeHandle. The correct handle will be initialized and used within CommitActionExecutor.
This was cleaner than an external merge Algorithm to be plugged into the HoodieMergeHandle because:

Sort in MergeHandle is closely tied to reading and writing the records. The algorithm is better suited to cases where all records are already available in memory.
Cleaner code as the intention is evident from the handle name.
Removes code duplication
No change for non-hfile base formats (the existing HoodieMergeHandle will be used).

Please take a look.

@nsivabalan : Yes, this is what I was referring to but it is not specific to Storage alone. Other parts like the merge algorithm that needs to be configured per storage-type is also created here.
@prashantwason : Let's revisit this in subsequent PR where we parameterize merge algorithm based on storage types. It is ok to keep reader and writer factory separate.
Please see above for AbstractFactory suggestion.
Looks like this is duplicated. Can you refactor to reuse this code.
Refactored and moved to HoodieFileWriter.
Instead of this, lets return merge algorithm to be employed.
See my comments above. I have created a new merge handle.

This is one another shuffle which will cause performance overhead. We dont need universal order. We only need to order records that are getting written to a single partition.
we should just do https://spark.apache.org/docs/1.2.0/api/java/org/apache/spark/rdd/OrderedRDDFunctions.html#repartitionAndSortWithinPartitions(org.apache.spark.Partitioner) when partitioning (See BaseCommitExecutor.java)
